qas.question: When was the earliest Presbyterian churches founded by Scotland in England?
In what year during the Presbyterian movement in England was referred to as the "Disruption"?
What did Scottish Immigrants to Columba found in the 19th century?
What did Scottish Immigrants to England found in the 20th century?
Beginning in what century did English immigrants from Scotland found Presbyterian churches?
What is the congregation that is located in the heart of Swallow Street called?
In what year did the Presbyterian Church of England become the Church of Scotland?

context: A number of new <b2_0><b3_0>Presbyterian Churches<b3_0/><b2_0/> were founded by Scottish immigrants to England in the <a0_0><b4_0>19th century<b4_0/><a0_0/> and later. Following the 'Disruption' in <a1_0>1843<a1_0/> many of those linked to the Church of Scotland eventually joined what became the Presbyterian Church of England in <b6_0>1876<b6_0/>. Some, that is Crown Court (Covent Garden, London), St Andrew's (Stepney, London) and Swallow Street (London), did not join the English denomination, which is why there are Church of Scotland congregations in England such as those at Crown Court, and St Columba's, Pont Street (Knightsbridge) in London. There is also a congregation in the heart of London's financial district called <b5_0>London City Presbyterian Church<b5_0/> that is also affiliated with Free Church of Scotland.
